name: building operation, budget hotel | building operation, budget hotel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20367/documentation

This dataset represents the operation of a tourist accommodation facility located in Junín, Peru. The case study hotel is classed as budget hotel (comfort category 3*). It was first opened in 2006 although the building where the hotel resides was constructed in 1957. Prior to becoming a hotel, the building was used as a farm. The hotel has capacity of 50 beds and offers 20 double-size rooms with double or twin beds, with additional capacity to install an extra single bed in each room in the periods of high demand and if and when required. The hotel is made up by 21 stand-alone buildings, where 20 buildings host guest rooms and 1 building represents an administrative building. All buildings have 1 floor. The administrative building hosts a lobby, a restaurant, a bar and a conference hall. There is a swimming pool (70 m2) and a parking lot (220 m2) for guest use on site. Laundry is available on site. The hotel occupies a total area of 420000 m2 which is the legacy of it being a farm in the past. The area in actual use (i.e. the area occupied by all hotel buildings and amenities) is 2181 m2 and the hotel's Gross Floor Area (GFA) is 1366 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hotel is 30% which is equal to 5475 guest nights per year. The hotel's occupancy is significantly lower than the country's average of 66%; (Source: Hotel News Now 2015. The state of Peru's tourism, hotels. Available from: http://www.hotelnewsnow.biz/Articles/27650/The-state-of-Perus-tourism-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018). This can in part be explained by the hotel location which is rather remote. This is also because of the hotel positioning itself as an eco-lodge which does not appeal to the mass consumer.

This dataset is modelled to represent the service of operating a hotel. It includes: energy and water consumption, furniture and in-room textiles (such as bed linen, bed mattrasses and curtains), electric and electronic equipment used in guest rooms and on hotel premises (including bulbs), cleaning and in-room consumables. The case study hotel has laundry on-site and this activity is included. Although the case study hotel has a restaurant on site, the inputs of food items have been excluded due to data availability. The energy and water consumption attibuted to restaurant operations have been included. Any waste generated in restaurant operations has been included. Activities include hotel operations and infrastructure based on 1 guest night stay and the lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. 

Activities end with guest departure from hotel premises. Due to data availability, the following processes have been excluded: room equipment (on-table lamp, door lock), bathroom equipment (showers, mirrors), kitchen equipment (mixer), food inputs in restaurant operations.
category: I:Accommodation and food service activities/55:Accommodation/551:Short term accommodation activities/5510:Short term accommodation activities

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hotel is located in Junín, Perú
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology in use is considered current.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of operations, energy and water consumption are aggregate and represent the case study hotel as a whole, rather than its specific operational areas (e.g. guest rooms, restaurant and bar). The comments to respective processes explain this in detail.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

exchanges.description: This reference product represents operation of a tourist accommodation facility classed as a budget hotel (comfort category 3*).

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Combined of all instances of use across the hotel operations. Represents the following cleaning luquids: window cleaner, bleach, washing up liquid, insect killer, pine disinfector, odour eliminator. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. As the product "cleaning consumables" is expressed as 100% active substance, the amount of cleaning consumables is multiplied by the average concentration of active substance. According to Golsteijn (2015) the average water content of cleaning consumables is 86.4%, the necessary water input is accounted for with the flow "water, compeltely softened, from decarbonised water, at user". For more information on how the cleaning consumables dataset was created please refer to the relevant dataset in ecoinvent.

2015, Laura Golsteijn, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

exchanges.description: Data from the hotel survey. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). The amount also includes electricity requirements to produce cotton textile products from raw cotton. It is estimated that 2 MJ of electricity is required to produce 1 kg of cotton textile product. This accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents all toiletries provided in guest rooms (soap, shampoo, shower gel and body lotion). The amount of luquid toiletries (shampoo and shower gel) is converted from the consumption volume expressed in ml, assuming 1 liter of shampoo and shower gel is equal to 1 kg of shampoo and shower gel. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater.

Calculated value. Represents here all chairs used across the hotel that are made of steel. Steel chair (unit) is assumed to have a weight of 12 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Acerage service life is assumed to be 15 years. This represents service life of an average piece of furniture. Source: European Commission 2013. BACKGROUND REPORT. Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group
Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. From the dataset for "cleaning consumables production" GLO 2011-2013, on average cleaning products contain 86% of water. Based on the literature source Golsteijn (2015) the dataset used to represent the water flow is "water, completely softened, at plant", version 2 dataset which corresponds to ecoinvent version 3 dataset "water, completely softened, from decarbonised waterm at user". The amount of water needed is therefore calculated based on the vale of 86% calculated based on Golsteijn (2015) and the amount of cleaning consumable which are expressed as 100% active substance.

Laura Golsteijn, 2015, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

exchanges.description: No data on the amount of water used was provided by the case study hotel. Hence, the data from the hotel of the same type (budget) but based in Rio de Janeiro (Brazil) were used as proxy with appropriate adjustments made to reflect the difference in occupancy (56% in the case of a budget hotel in Brazil compared to 30% in the case of a budget hotel in Peru).

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Represents here pouffees used by the case study hotel that are made of PVC. Pouffee is assumed to have a weight of 5 kg. Source: Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Average service life of a pouffee is assumed to be equal to 15 years which is equal to service life for an average piece of furniture. Source: European Commission 2013. BACKGROUND REPORT. Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group
Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018.

exchanges.description:
Estimated value. Assumed average service life of all pieces of furniture is 15 years. This represents service life of an average piece of furniture. Source: European Commission 2013. BACKGROUND REPORT. Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018. 
This exchange represents the following: Bed single (unit). Assumed to have a weight of 21 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Bed king/queen (unit). King bed is assumed to have a weight of 30 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Sofa (unit). Sofa is assumed to have a weight of 37 kg, two seater, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Table / desk (unit). Table unit is assumed to have a weight of 23 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Chair (unit). Chair is assumed to have a weight of 7 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Wardrobe (unit). Wardrobe is assumed to have a weight of 55 kg, double wardrobe, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Furniture is combined across all instances of use within the hotel building.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents here the total number of cotton-made linen units and cotton-made curtains used by the hotel. For linen, it is assumed that, on average, 4 linen units make 1 kg in weight. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19, 1917-1930. Assumed average service life is 0.25 years. Source: TRSA 2015. Hospitality Textile Life, Loss and Replacement. Available from: http://www.laundrycompliance.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/trsa-hospitality-hotel-linen-loss.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018. For curtains, it is assumed that a curtain has a weight of 5 kg. Source: Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018.  Average service life of a curtain is assumed to be equal to average service life of a carpet which is 10 years. Source: Greenspec 2018. While life costing: carpets. Available from: http://www.greenspec.co.uk/building-design/carpets/ Accessed 16 March 2018. The amount accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.
